AboutCard.title: About this index
AboutCard.description: Search results are based on the DOJ multimedia-search index. PDF links open in a new tab on DOJ.gov.
AboutCard.feature1: Fast search mode uses indexed DOJ text.
AboutCard.feature2: Deep analysis fetches the PDF on-demand.

AboutPage.title: About | DOJ Epstein Files Search
AboutPage.metaDescription: Learn about the DOJ Epstein Files AI Search tool, our data sources, AI technology, and mission to make legal documents accessible.
AboutPage.heading: About DOJ Epstein Files Search
AboutPage.intro: This project provides free, AI-powered access to over 2,000 Department of Justice documents related to the Jeffrey Epstein case.
AboutPage.mission: Making legal documents accessible to journalists, researchers, and the public through advanced AI technology and conversational search.
AboutPage.dataSource: All documents are sourced directly from the official DOJ.gov multimedia search index. We do not host or modify any PDFs - all links point to original government sources.
AboutPage.technology: We use Groq's Llama 3.3 70B model for AI summaries, Playwright for document scraping, and Redis for caching. The search interface is built with Next.js and deployed on Vercel.
AboutPage.privacy: We don't track users, sell data, or require accounts. All searches are anonymous. Rate limiting prevents abuse while keeping the service free for everyone.
AboutPage.howItWorks: When you enter a search query, our system queries the DOJ multimedia search API in real-time. Results are ranked by relevance and word count. You can then generate an AI summary of the search results (Fast mode) or perform deep analysis on individual PDFs (Deep mode). All document links point directly to official DOJ.gov sources—we act as a search interface and analysis layer, not a document host.
AboutPage.documentTypes: The searchable archive includes court filings, indictments, victim impact statements, depositions, flight logs, correspondence, financial records, and other legal documents released by the Department of Justice. Each document type provides different insights into the case proceedings and investigations.
AboutPage.openSource: This project is open source and available on GitHub. The codebase includes the Next.js frontend, Express worker service, and all API integrations. Contributions, bug reports, and feature requests are welcome. We believe transparency in code matches our commitment to transparency in legal document access.

PrivacyPage.title: Privacy Policy | DOJ Epstein Files Search
PrivacyPage.metaDescription: Privacy policy for DOJ Epstein Files Search. Learn about data collection, cookies, third-party services, and GDPR compliance.
PrivacyPage.heading: Privacy Policy
PrivacyPage.intro: We are committed to protecting your privacy. This policy explains what data we collect and how we use it.
PrivacyPage.dataCollection: We collect minimal data: IP addresses for rate limiting (stored temporarily), search queries (not linked to users), and anonymized usage statistics. We do NOT collect personal information, emails, or create user profiles.
PrivacyPage.cookies: We use localStorage to save your chat history locally in your browser. If you opt in, advertising cookies are used for Google AdSense. You can change your choice at any time.
PrivacyPage.consent: When required by law (EEA/UK/CH), we request consent before loading advertising cookies. Your choice is stored with a timestamp, policy version, and locale for compliance auditing.
PrivacyPage.adsense: If you consent, Google AdSense may set cookies to deliver ads, measure performance, and prevent fraud. If you decline, ads may be less relevant.
PrivacyPage.withdraw: You can withdraw or change consent anytime using “Cookie preferences” in the header or by revisiting this page.
PrivacyPage.thirdParty: We use: Upstash (Redis caching), Groq (AI summaries), Vercel (hosting), and Google AdSense for advertising (only with consent). Each has their own privacy policy.
PrivacyPage.gdpr: EU users have the right to access, delete, or export their data. Since we don't store personal data, there's nothing to export. Clear your browser's localStorage to remove chat history.
PrivacyPage.contact: For privacy concerns, please open an issue on our GitHub repository.

FAQPage.title: FAQ | DOJ Epstein Files Search
FAQPage.metaDescription: Frequently asked questions about searching DOJ Epstein documents, AI summaries, data sources, and how to use the search tool effectively.
FAQPage.heading: Frequently Asked Questions
FAQPage.intro: Quick answers to the most common questions about the DOJ Epstein search, AI summaries, and source documents.
FAQPage.a1: You can search over 2,000 documents from the DOJ Epstein case, including court filings, victim statements, flight logs, and other legal records released by the Department of Justice.
FAQPage.q2: How does the AI search work?
FAQPage.a2: Fast mode searches the DOJ's indexed text and generates a summary. Deep mode downloads the full PDF and performs comprehensive analysis. Both use Groq's Llama 3.3 70B AI model.
FAQPage.a3: Yes. All PDF links point directly to DOJ.gov. We don't host, modify, or alter any documents. We only search and summarize them.
FAQPage.a4: Yes, completely free. We use rate limiting to prevent abuse. If you hit the limit, wait a few minutes and try again. Donations help cover hosting costs.
FAQPage.a5: Yes. Click any PDF link in the search results to open the original document on DOJ.gov. You can download from there.
FAQPage.q6: How accurate are the AI summaries?
FAQPage.a6: Summaries are generated by AI and may contain errors. Always verify important information by reading the source PDF. Summaries are meant to help you find relevant documents quickly.
FAQPage.a7: This is an independent open-source project built to make legal documents more accessible. We have no affiliation with the DOJ or any parties involved in the case.
FAQPage.q8: What is the Epstein case about?
FAQPage.a8: The Jeffrey Epstein case involves charges of sex trafficking and conspiracy. The Department of Justice released extensive documentation related to federal investigations, court proceedings, and victim testimonies. Our search tool helps you discover and analyze these official legal documents.
FAQPage.q9: How often is the database updated?
FAQPage.a9: The database reflects the DOJ's official document releases. When new documents are published by the Department of Justice, they become searchable through our system. We do not add or modify documents—all content comes directly from DOJ sources.
FAQPage.q10: Can I search in languages other than English?
FAQPage.a10: The interface is available in 6 languages (English, Dutch, French, German, Spanish, Portuguese), but the underlying documents are official DOJ records in English. AI summaries are generated in your selected language.
FAQPage.q11: What are Fast and Deep search modes?
FAQPage.a11: Fast mode searches indexed text from the DOJ database and generates quick AI summaries. Deep mode downloads the full PDF, extracts all text, and performs comprehensive analysis—useful for detailed research but slower. Both modes use the same AI model.
FAQPage.a12: No. Search queries are processed in real-time and not linked to any user identity. Your chat history is stored locally in your browser via localStorage. We do not track searches, create profiles, or store personal data on our servers.

TimelinePage.title: Timeline | DOJ Epstein Files Search
TimelinePage.metaDescription: Chronological timeline of the Jeffrey Epstein case, from investigation through court proceedings and document releases. Key dates and milestones from DOJ records.
TimelinePage.heading: Case Timeline
TimelinePage.intro: A chronological overview of key events in the Jeffrey Epstein case based on official Department of Justice records and court filings.
TimelinePage.investigation: The investigation into Jeffrey Epstein began in 2005 following allegations of abuse. In 2008, Epstein pleaded guilty to state charges in Florida under a controversial plea deal. Federal investigations resumed in 2019, leading to his July 2019 indictment on federal sex trafficking charges. Epstein was arrested and detained at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York.
TimelinePage.arrest: On July 6, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was arrested at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey. Federal prosecutors charged him with sex trafficking of minors and conspiracy. He was denied bail and held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. The indictment detailed allegations spanning from 2002 to 2005, involving dozens of underage victims.
TimelinePage.death: On August 10, 2019, Epstein was found dead in his cell. The death was ruled a suicide by the New York City medical examiner. His death halted criminal proceedings against him but did not end related investigations or civil litigation involving alleged co-conspirators and enablers.
TimelinePage.releases: Following Epstein's death, numerous legal proceedings led to the release of thousands of pages of court documents, depositions, and evidence. The Department of Justice released case materials through various court orders and Freedom of Information Act requests. These documents include victim testimonies, flight logs, financial records, and correspondence. Additional releases continue as ongoing litigation proceeds.

KeyFiguresPage.title: Key Figures | DOJ Epstein Files Search
KeyFiguresPage.metaDescription: Overview of key figures in the Epstein case documented in DOJ records, including defendants, witnesses, and investigators.
KeyFiguresPage.heading: Key Figures
KeyFiguresPage.intro: Individuals frequently mentioned in the Department of Justice case documents. This information is based solely on publicly released legal records.
KeyFiguresPage.epstein: Jeffrey Epstein was a financier and convicted sex offender. He faced federal charges of sex trafficking of minors and conspiracy to engage in sex trafficking. The DOJ indictment alleged he sexually exploited and abused dozens of minor girls at his residences in Manhattan, New York, and Palm Beach, Florida, among other locations. Epstein died in federal custody on August 10, 2019, before standing trial on the federal charges.
KeyFiguresPage.maxwell: Ghislaine Maxwell, a British socialite and Epstein associate, was indicted in July 2020 on federal charges including enticement of minors, sex trafficking of children, and perjury. Court documents allege she assisted Epstein in recruiting, grooming, and abusing underage victims. In December 2021, she was convicted on five counts and is currently serving a 20-year federal prison sentence.
KeyFiguresPage.victims: The DOJ case files include testimonies from numerous victims and witnesses. Many victims provided impact statements describing abuse that occurred when they were minors. Their testimonies form the foundation of the federal case and subsequent civil litigation. Names of victims are often redacted in public documents to protect their privacy.
KeyFiguresPage.investigators: The case involved the FBI, Department of Justice prosecutors, and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York. Prosecutors presented evidence of Epstein's alleged criminal enterprise to a grand jury, resulting in the federal indictment. Following Epstein's death, investigations continued into potential co-conspirators and enablers.
KeyFiguresPage.searchPrompt: Search for a name to find related documents in the DOJ archive.
